definition.title: What is an Elevator Pitch?
definition.content: An elevator pitch is a brief, persuasive speech that communicates who you are, what you do, and why it matters—all within 30 seconds (about 75-90 words). The goal isn't to close the deal, but to earn interest for a longer conversation.

landingContent.formula: [Hook] → [Problem You Solve] → [Your Unique Solution] → [Proof/Credibility] → [Call to Action]
tips: Start with a hook that grabs attention - a surprising stat, question, or bold statement
Clearly articulate the problem you solve - make them feel the pain
Highlight your unique approach - what makes you different?
Include credibility markers - numbers, clients, or results
End with a clear call to action or conversation opener

examples.title: 30-Second Pitch
examples.content: You know how most entrepreneurs struggle to get consistent leads? I help business owners generate a predictable pipeline of qualified prospects using AI-powered marketing systems. My clients typically see a 300% increase in leads within 90 days. Would love to hear what's working for you.

examples.title: 60-Second Pitch
examples.content: Every day, talented coaches watch their competitors fill programs while they struggle with inconsistent revenue. I've spent 10 years developing a system that helps coaches land high-ticket clients through strategic podcast guesting. Last month alone, my clients collectively generated over $500K in new business. Curious what that could look like for you?

examples.title: Problem-Focused Hook
examples.content: Most founders spend 80% of their time on activities that generate zero revenue. I help them flip that ratio so they can scale without burning out.

faq.question: How long should my elevator pitch be?
faq.answer: Aim for 30 seconds (about 75-90 words). This is enough time to share your value without losing attention.

faq.question: Should I memorize my pitch word-for-word?
faq.answer: Know the key points, but keep it conversational. Practice until you can deliver it naturally in any situation.

faq.question: How do I end my pitch?
faq.answer: End with a question or invitation to continue the conversation, like 'Does that sound like something you've experienced?'

faq.question: Should I have multiple versions?
faq.answer: Yes! Create variations for different audiences - what works at a tech conference differs from a general networking event.
